title: Sampling Theory
text:
THIS IS the key point

We assume that the distribution of sample means is normal.
We use that assumption to gauge the probability of getting a particular mean from a single sample.
We can literally find that probability, the same way we did with x-values in a normal distribution.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Example
We want to know how much people like pizza.

There are 12,500 people in our population.
Each of the 25 of us collects a sample of 500.
(500 x 25 = 12,500)
\(500 \times 25 = 12,500\)
Each of us calculates the mean response from our sample of 500 people.
We plot those means and it gives us a normal distribution.
What do we call those means?

Sampling Theory is the body of principles underlying the drawing of infinite samples that accurately represent the population from which they are taken and to which inferences can be made.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Sampling theory

Sampling Theory is the idea that if we took infinite samples of a population, they would create a normal distribution.


And because they’d create a normal distribution, we can make guesses about the probability of getting a specific mean.
We will use this probability to gauge significance of our inferential statistics.

title: Sampling Theory

The mean of a sample is notated as M.
The mean of a population is notated as (\(\mu\)).

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Sampling theory

The dispersion of a sample is known as the standard deviation, or SD, or sometimes just s.
The dispersion of a population cannot be a “deviation” because we don’t actually know it. So instead, we call it the Standard Error, or SE, or most often (sigma).

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Rejects and Failures

In science, we do not say that we proved anything.
Nothing is ever really proven.
Our findings will be stated in terms of the Null Hypothesis.
The Null Hypothesis is that there are no differences between the groups.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Hypothesis testing practice

Jonas assigns half of the participants to engage in aerobic exercise for one hour a day 5 days a week for 6 months. The other half of the participants do not exercise for 6 months. At the end of the 6 months, Jonas measures the participants’ working memory capacity.

\(H_0\): There are no differences in working memory capacity between the experimental and control groups.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Rejects and Failures

In science, we do not say that we proved anything.
Our findings will be stated in terms of the Null Hypothesis.
If there are significant differences between the groups, we Reject the \(H_0\).

Rejecting is good.

If there are NO differences between the groups, we Fail to Reject the \(H_0\).

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Hypothesis Testing
When reporting your findings, you must state them in terms of the Null Hypothesis. We do not mention the Alternative Hypothesis.

If the groups differ, we reject the null hypothesis: Reject \(H_0\).
If the groups do NOT differ, we fail: Fail to Reject \(H_0\)

title: Syllabus
text:
Prerequisites/Corequisites: PSY 101 and MTH 110
Meeting Days and Times:
Lecture: M/W 9:25 AM – 10:40 AM
Laboratory: Monday 10:50 AM - 11:40 AM
Meeting Room: Whitman Hall B26
Instructor: Dave Brocker, M.A.
Email: brockeda@farmingdale.edu
Phone: (934) 420 5678
Office: Knapp Hall 15



This course will introduce students to the basic descriptive and inferential statistics used in the behavioral and social sciences. Topics will include the organization of data, measures of central tendency and variability, correlation and regression, hypothesis testing, and various parametric and nonparametric tests of significance including t-tests and ANOVA. Students will focus on the interconnections between theory, statistical techniques, and research methods in order to identify the appropriate statistical tests to analyze data and reach objective conclusions regarding research questions in the social sciences. The course will provide practice in using statistical software for data summarization, presentation, and analysis.




As a result of this course, students will be able to understand statistical terms and research reports in the social sciences, use statistical techniques to analyze experimental data for hypothesis testing, and use statistical software to aid in the presentation and analysis of quantitative data.
To accomplish these objectives, students will be able to:

Describe the four measurement scales (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio).
Construct frequency distributions and represent them graphically.
Identify and calculate measures of central tendency including mean, median, and mode.
Define and calculate measures of variability including variance and standard deviation.
Calculate and apply the use of z-scores.
Describe the normal curve and use the curve to solve various problems including probability.
Appraise the difference between populations and samples.
Apply the concepts of sampling theory and sampling distributions to statistical testing.
Explain and apply the basic concepts of hypothesis testing including the null, significance testing, and errors.
Calculate and appraise correlation coefficients.
Obtain and graph regression equations and use results to make predictions.
Test for significant differences between means using t-tests.
Calculate and interpret analysis of variance and follow up comparisons.
Determine appropriate hypothesis test based on research questions and level of data.
Evaluate how appropriate measures are by measuring reliability and validity.
Perform statistical techniques by hand using formulas and with statistical software.
Interpret the results of inferential statistical techniques.





Course Materials
There is no required text for this course.
Selected readings will be made available on Brightspace.
Course Format
This course has both lecture and laboratory components. During lecture on Monday and Wednesday, we will discuss statistical theory and prepare for the corresponding laboratory by examining computational formulas. We will also work through practice examples to prepare you for the recitation.
On Monday afternoons we will meet for recitation. I will guide you through the first half of the lab for that day, and students will be given the remainder of the recitation period to complete the second portion of the lab. Students will complete the labs using statistical software accessed on the computers in our classroom.



Exams (36%) – 12 points each
There will be three non-cumulative exams. Each of the exams will contain two parts: conceptional and computational. The conceptual part of the exam will include 12 multiple choice questions pertaining to theory we covered in lecture. Each multiple choice question will be worth 0.5 points for a total of 6 points. The computational part of the exam will contain 2 to 3 questions with various parts, each worth a different point value. The computational portion will require you to apply the concepts we learned in lecture and the skills we learn in recitation.
Labs (54%) – 4.5 points each
In recitation each week, students will complete a 5-point lab assignment that corresponds to the lectures given the week before. Each lab will contain two parts. We will complete the first part together as a class. Working along with the class to complete the first part is worth 1.5 points. The second part is to be completed by students on their own or in small groups and is worth the remaining 3 points.
Attendance and Participation (10%)
This course requires attendance and active participation, as the material increases in difficulty over the course of the semester. Each student is allowed 2 absences without penalty, so long as missed work is made up in a timely manner. Students who are absence more than twice, should meet with me to discuss how they will keep up with the course material.



Your final grade will be based on the following grading scale provided by the college. PLEASE NOTE: To be fair to everyone, these are exact cutoffs. Under no circumstances can I round up the grade of any student. ALSO NOTE: Your grade in Brightspace may not accurately reflect your grade in this course, as some grade-related material will not be updated there, such as participation. For an estimation of your grade at any point during the semester, please email me. I’d be happy to tell you your current estimated grade.

Cancellation of Classes:
Weather and other campus-wide cancellations will be listed on the home page, Facebook and Twitter and you can also sign up for RAVE and SUNY Alert. Go to GETRAVE and use your Farmingdale user ID and password to enter the site. For SUNY-Alert, please visit the University Police web page at University Police. If I need to cancel class for any other reason, I will post an announcement on Brightspace and email students a copy of the announcement.
Electronic Devices Policy:
Technology use in the classroom is intended to enhance the learning environment for all students. Accordingly, use of laptops, notebook computers, and tablets is allowed in and during class so long as they are being used to take notes and they are put in silent mode so that notifications do not sound during class.
Cellphones should be put in silent mode and kept out of sight, unless there are extenuating circumstances (for example, you have a child who is being cared by someone while you are in class and you must be reachable). If you feel you need to have your cell phone out during class time for a legitimate reason, please email me.
Classroom Recording:
The recording of classroom instruction is for the sole purpose of supporting the course learning objectives and can only be accessible to FSC faculty, staff, and students. Capturing, copying, and or sharing of recordings is strictly prohibited. Students not adhering to campus policies would be in violation of the student code of conduct.
Attendance Policy:
This course requires attendance and active participation, as the material increases in difficulty over the course of the semester. Each student is allowed 2 absences without penalty, so long as missed work is made up in a timely manner. Students who are absence more than twice, should meet with me to discuss how they will keep up with the course material.
Religious Absences:
If you are unable to attend class on certain days due to religious beliefs, please consult with your instructor well in advance of the absence so that appropriate accommodation can be made. Reasonable accommodation in course work may be unavailable if a request results in a significant number of absences or substantially impacts class participation. Please note a significant number of absences is viewed as greater than 5% of class time.
Use of Email:
It is College policy that instructors and students use the Farmingdale email system or the Brightspace email system to contact one another.
Copyright Statement:
Course material accessed from Brightspace or the Farmingdale website is for the exclusive use of students who are currently enrolled in the course. Content from these systems cannot be reused or distributed without written permission of the instructor and/or the copyright holder. Duplication of materials protected by copyright, without permission of the copyright holder, is a violation of the Federal copyright law, as well as a violation of SUNY copyright policy.
Disability Services Center:
If you have a disability for which you are or may be requesting an accommodation, you are encouraged to contact both your instructor and the Disability Services Center, Sinclair Hall, Room 185, or call 934-420-2411, or 934-420–2607 as soon as possible this semester.
Campus Mental Health Services
Occasionally, students may experience problems related to excessive stress, anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues. All registered students at Farmingdale State College have access to Campus Mental Health Services, located in Sinclair Hall. There is no fee for services.
CMHS provides both short and long-term treatment for anxiety, mood disorders, acute and chronic stress disorders, and other emotional or behavioral problems that may adversely impact students’ functioning. Additionally, CMHS is available 24/7 for students who may be in crisis. You are encouraged to contact CMHS at (934) 420-2006 or cmhs@farmingdale.edu if you are having difficulties in the above areas. We are also available for consultation to help you determine whether or not services may be helpful.
Academic Integrity Policy
Because intellectual honesty is a cornerstone of all academic and scholarly work, each member of the Farmingdale State College campus community is expected to maintain academic integrity. Farmingdale State College has developed regulations concerning academic dishonesty and integrity to protect all students and to maintain an ethical academic environment. For more information, click the updated link below: Policies
It is important for you to understand the concept of plagiarism. Plagiarism is intentionally representing the words,images or ideas of another as one’s own in any academic exercise. This includes words, images or ideas in either print or electronic format.
Students who plagiarize will automatically fail the plagiarized assignment. This includes use of AI to complete writing assignments. All previously submitted assignments will then be re-assessed for plagiarism, and if plagiarism is found in any prior assignments, the grades of those assignments will also be changed to an F. I will also report any student who plagiarizes to the Dean of Students.
Diversity Equity & Inclusion:
Farmingdale State College embraces the belief that our intellectual community is enriched and enhanced by the opportunity to learn from and appreciate diversity. We strive to have a curriculum and learning environment which respects, honors and incorporates the contributions of a diverse and inclusive teaching and learning community. Your person (identity) and voice are welcomed in this classroom environment because of your value as a member of FSC’s inclusive and diverse culture. All members of this class are expected to contribute to a respectful, welcoming and inclusive environment for every other member of the class.
Student Code of Conduct

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Materials
There is no required text for this course.
Selected readings will be made available on Brightspace.
Course Format
This course has both lecture and laboratory components. During lecture on Monday and Wednesday, we will discuss statistical theory and prepare for the corresponding laboratory by examining computational formulas. We will also work through practice examples to prepare you for the recitation.
On Monday afternoons we will meet for recitation. I will guide you through the first half of the lab for that day, and students will be given the remainder of the recitation period to complete the second portion of the lab. Students will complete the labs using statistical software accessed on the computers in our classroom.

title: Syllabus
text:
Exams (36%) – 12 points each
There will be three non-cumulative exams. Each of the exams will contain two parts: conceptional and computational. The conceptual part of the exam will include 12 multiple choice questions pertaining to theory we covered in lecture. Each multiple choice question will be worth 0.5 points for a total of 6 points. The computational part of the exam will contain 2 to 3 questions with various parts, each worth a different point value. The computational portion will require you to apply the concepts we learned in lecture and the skills we learn in recitation.
Labs (54%) – 4.5 points each
In recitation each week, students will complete a 5-point lab assignment that corresponds to the lectures given the week before. Each lab will contain two parts. We will complete the first part together as a class. Working along with the class to complete the first part is worth 1.5 points. The second part is to be completed by students on their own or in small groups and is worth the remaining 3 points.
Attendance and Participation (10%)
This course requires attendance and active participation, as the material increases in difficulty over the course of the semester. Each student is allowed 2 absences without penalty, so long as missed work is made up in a timely manner. Students who are absence more than twice, should meet with me to discuss how they will keep up with the course material.

Cellphones should be put in silent mode and kept out of sight, unless there are extenuating circumstances (for example, you have a child who is being cared by someone while you are in class and you must be reachable). Campus Mental Health Services
Occasionally, students may experience problems related to excessive stress, anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues. All registered students at Farmingdale State College have access to Campus Mental Health Services, located in Sinclair Hall. There is no fee for services.
CMHS provides both short and long-term treatment for anxiety, mood disorders, acute and chronic stress disorders, and other emotional or behavioral problems that may adversely impact students’ functioning. Additionally, CMHS is available 24/7 for students who may be in crisis. You are encouraged to contact CMHS at (934) 420-2006 or cmhs@farmingdale.edu if you are having difficulties in the above areas. Academic Integrity Policy
Because intellectual honesty is a cornerstone of all academic and scholarly work, each member of the Farmingdale State College campus community is expected to maintain academic integrity. Farmingdale State College has developed regulations concerning academic dishonesty and integrity to protect all students and to maintain an ethical academic environment. For more information, click the updated link below: Policies

title: Dispersion

Calculating Dispersion
How do think we should calculate dispersion?

When we squared the deviation scores in Step 3, we inflated the deviation.

We have to undo that inflation.
How do you undo squaring?
We take the square root.

title: Dispersion
text:
Calculating standard deviation

Mean: Calculate the mean.
Deviation scores: Subtract the mean from each x-value.
Squared deviations: Square each deviation score.
Sum of squares: Add up the squared deviations.
Variance: Divide the sum of squares by (n-1).
Standard Deviation: Take the square root of the variance.

title: Dispersion
text:
Formulas for Dispersion
Variance
\[
s^2 = \frac{\sum(x-\bar{x})^2}{N-1}
\]

title: Dispersion
text:
Formulas for Dispersion
Standard Deviation
\[
s = \sqrt{\frac{\sum(x-\bar{x})^2}{N-1}}
\]

Variance is a measure of dispersion.

It’s not helpful, because it’s inflated (from squaring the deviation scores).

Standard deviation is a better measure of dispersion, because it is standardized.

This means that a standard deviation of 1 means a distance of 1 on the scale used to measure x.
HYPE scale: 1 to 10: standard deviation of 1 means the distance from one rating to the next, from 1 to 2.
If the mean = 5, SD = 1, most scores fall between 4 and 6.

title: Dispersion
text:
Variance & Standard deviation

The Variance is the standard deviation squared: s²
The Standard Deviation is the square root of the variance: s

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Standard Normal Distribution
The 4 properties of a standard normal distribution are:
• They are shaped like a bell (“bell curve”).
• They are symmetric.
• They are unimodal.
• The mean = median = mode.

The mean, median, and mode are all the same in a normal distribution.

title: Standard Normal Distribution

This means a standard deviation of 1 means a distance of 1 on the scale used to measure the variable.

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-scores
A z-score tells you in standard deviation units how far the x-value is from the mean.

Z-scores are better than using raw SD, because when the SD is a decimal, it is hard to find the exact point under the standard normal curve.

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-scores:
The distance from the mean to the 1 on this standard normal curve is equal to the SD.
The distance from the mean to the 1 on this standard normal curve is equal to z=1.

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-scores
Z-scores re-express the original data points (the X’s) in a way that intuitively lets us know:

How close the X is to the mean (AKA how much this particular participant is like the average person in the sample)
Where it falls in the dispersion of the distribution (AKA how different this particular participant is from the majority of people in the sample)

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Calculating
Z-scores

Subtract the mean from each X value.
Divide by the standard deviation.

\[
z = \frac{x-\bar{x}}{s}
\]

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-scores
Z-Scores are calculated by:

Centering the X values on the mean: When we center the mean (AKA mean-centering), we set the mean to 0.
Dividing by the standard deviation: When we divide by the SD, the space from the mean is expressed in standard deviations.

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-scores

We made the mean = 0: When you mean-center a distribution, you shift it along the number line.
We made the SD = 1: When you divide a distribution by the SD, you shrink the distribution down.
BUT: The shape of the distribution remains the same.

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-scores
Shift distribution along the number line.
Shrink distribution down.
The shape of the distribution remains the same.

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-Scores
Why Do We Care?

A z-score tells me where my score falls in SD units.
I can then look at this standard normal curve, and estimate what percentage of people did better or worse than me.

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-Scores
Why Do We Care?
The mean score for Exam 1 was a 92 with a standard deviation of 3.

Esmeralda scored an 86.
What percent of the class scored better than Esmeralda?

\(z=\frac{x-\bar{x}}{s}\)
\(z = \frac{86-92}{3} = -2\)

86-92/3 = -2
98% of the class did better than Esmeralda.

title: Standard Normal Distribution
text:
Z-Scores
The mean score for Exam 1 was a 92 with a standard deviation of 3.
Jonas scored a 95.

What percent of the class scored better than Jonas?

\[
z = \frac{95-92}{3} = 1
\]
16% scored higher than Jonas.

title: Operationalization
text:
Operationalization

The process of defining the measurement of a phenomenon that is not directly measurable (AKA a latent variable) though its existence is implied by other phenomena.

title: Operationalization
text:
Operationalization
Figuring out how to measure something you can’t directly measure.

Acquiescence


Tendency to say yes, true, agree


Social desirability


Tendency to respond in ways that are seen as socially acceptable


Demand characteristics


Tendency to response in ways that participant thinks researcher wants

title: Operationalization
text:
Self-report:
Avoiding Disadvantages

Anonymous respondents are less likely to make things up

Assure anonymity



Allow respondents to answer in private

Allow for maximum privacy



Don’t make your experiment too obvious/revealing

Obscure the true goal of the experiment



Add questions that test for respondent awareness

Include attention checks



Purposely make some questions opposite

Reverse coding

title: Operationalization
text:
Issues with Operationalization
Why is it hard to measure psychological phenomena?

Others may choose to measure the phenomena differently from us
Operationalization can be culture-specific
What we measure is based on observable parts of the phenomena, but some parts may be unobservable

Measuring only the observable/reportable is imprecise

title: Operationalization
text:

Observer children for one hour and…

Label them as Aggressive or Non-Aggressive
Rank them from most aggressive to least aggressive
Score them on a 10-point scale.

1 = No Aggression
10 = All of the Aggression

title: Operationalization
text:
Scales of measurement

Labels
Rank
Scale

title: Operationalization
text:
Scales of measurement

Nominal
Order
Interval
Ratio

title: Operationalization
text:
Measurement scales: Nominal
Nominal, like name, refers to categories that CANNOT be ordered:

Condition (experimental, control)
Gender
Major in college
Coffee drinker versus Non-coffee drinker (aka sociopath)

title: Operationalization
text:
Measurement scales: Ordinal
Ordinal, like order, refers to categories that CAN be ordered, but the space between each category isn’t necessarily the same:

Olympic Medals
Winner in a Race
Your rank in this class

title: Operationalization
text:
Measurement scales: Interval
Interval refers to ratings that are ordered where the interval between each rating is the same, but there is no real “0.”

Temperature*
“On a scale of 1-10 How much do you agree with the following statement…”

title: Operationalization
text:
Measurement scales: Ratio
Ratio, refers to ratings that are ordered, the interval between each rating is the same, and “0” means “0.”

Length
Reaction Time
Dosage

title: Operationalization
text:
Ordinal Scales

Rarely used in psychological research, because it is hard to calculate variance when the interval between each number differs.
There are non-parametric statistics designed for ordinal scales, but we will not be covering those this semester.

title: Operationalization
text:
Interval vs Ratio
What’s the difference between interval and ratio?

Interval may have a 0 on the scale, but it doesn’t mean the absence of something. A 0.0 GPA means an F rather than the absence of a grade.
Ratio has a 0 that. means 0 (the absence of something), like a ‘0’ as a response to the questions, “How many drinks did you have last night?”

title: Operationalization
text:
Determining Scale of measurement
Identify the scale of measurement.
Undergraduates report their self-esteem on a scale of 1 to 10. Researchers assess the relationship of undergraduates’ self-esteem and GPA.

Predictor variable: Self-Esteem | Continuous (Interval)
Outcome variable: GPA | Continuous (Interval)

title: Operationalization
text:
Determining Scale of measurement
Identify the scale of measurement.
Participants are given a mystery drug or placebo and then asked to complete puzzle tasks. Researchers time how long participants take to complete the puzzles.

Independent variable: Drug vs. Placebo Categorical (Nominal)
Dependent variable: Reaction Time | Continuous (Ratio)

title: Operationalization
text:
Determining Scale of measurement
Identify the scale of measurement.
Undergraduates are shown either pictures of death or pictures of landscapes. They then report their anxiety about aging on a scale of 1 (none) to 10 (lots).

Independent variable: Pictures of death versus landscapes | Categorical (Nominal)
Dependent variable: Anxiety about dying | Continuous (Interval)

title: Operationalization
section: WHY does scale of measurement matter?
text:
WHY does scale of measurement matter?

Statistical tests can only be run on specific scales of measurement.
t-test & ANOVA: Nominal IV/predictor and Continuous DV/outcome
Correlation & Regression: All continuous

title: Operationalization
section: Why does scale of measurement matter?
text:
Why does scale of measurement matter?

Generally, continuous variables (interval and ratio scales) lend themselves better to statistical analysis.
As a researcher, you should plan out your statistical analysis BEFORE conducting your study, so that you measure your variables in a way that matches the type of analyses you will run.
TAKE AWAY: How we measure variables matters because it dictates what kind of statistical analyses we can run.

title: Operationalization
text: Statistical terms & Symbols

title: Operationalization
text:
Statistical terms

Population

Every person in the group I am interested in studying

Sample

A small subset of people from the population who we will actually study in our experiment.

Parameter:

Information about the population.

Statistic

Information about the sample.

title: Operationalization
text:
Statistical Symbols
Case-sensitive and often Greek

\(n\) = the number of people in the sample
\(x\) = one datapoint in a sample
\(\bar{x}\) = Arithmetic mean (average) for a sample, x
\(\Sigma(x)\) = The sum of all values in a sample, x
\(\sum^{n}_{i = 1} = x_1 +x_2+x_3...\)

The 4 properties of a standard normal distribution are:

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Standard Normal Distribution
The 4 properties of a standard normal distribution are:

• They are shaped like a bell (“bell curve”).
• They are symmetric.
• They are unimodal.
• The mean = median = mode.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Statistics

Descriptive Statistics:

Goal: Describe the sample
Examples: Mean, Standard Deviation

Inferential Statistics:

Goal: Use the sample to make inferences about the population
Examples: t-test, ANOVA, Regression

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Sampling theory

Professor Brocker still wants to know how much adults in the US enjoy the Netflix Original, Dark. She has unlimited funds to study this very important research question. She hires her 24 students from to collect the data.


Each student has to collect 500 responses to the following question:

text:
Sampling theory

On a scale of 1 (I hate it with my entire being) to 10 (I believe in my soul that Dark is the best show ever made), how much do you enjoy Dark?

These are called Sample Means

We can do lots of cool things with Sample Means. We could calculate the Mean of the Sample Means. We could calculate the standard deviation of the Sample Means.

title: Sampling Theory

Probability

What percentage of participants rated Dark with a z-score of 2 or HIGHER?

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Probability

This is the distribution of sample means from adults in the US.
What is the probability of any sample having a mean that is a z-score of 2 or HIGHER?

title: Sampling Theory
text:
THIS IS the key point

We assume that the distribution of sample means is normal.
We use that assumption to gauge the probability of getting a particular mean from a single sample.
We can literally find that probability, the same way we did with x-values in a normal distribution.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Example
We want to know how much people like pizza.

There are 12,500 people in our population.
Each of the 25 of us collects a sample of 500.
(500 x 25 = 12,500)
\(500 \times 25 = 12,500\)
Each of us calculates the mean response from our sample of 500 people.
We plot those means and it gives us a normal distribution.
What do we call those means?

text:

What is the probability of picking a mean with a z-score of -1 or less?

Sampling theory

Sampling Theory is the body of principles underlying the drawing of infinite samples that accurately represent the population from which they are taken and to which inferences can be made.

title: Sampling Theory
section: Sampling theory as the basis for inferential statistics
text:
Sampling theory as the basis for inferential statistics

Independent variable:

Experimental Group: Super secret limitless drug

Control Group: Placebo

Dependent variable: IQ

title: Sampling Theory
section: Sampling theory as the basis for inferential statistics
text:
Sampling theory as the basis for inferential statistics
[Insert picture from slideset with two peaks]

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Review

Sampling distribution:
Sample mean:

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Sampling theory

Sampling Theory is the idea that if we took infinite samples of a population, they would create a normal distribution.


And because they’d create a normal distribution, we can make guesses about the probability of getting a specific mean.
We will use this probability to gauge significance of our inferential statistics.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Sampling theory

The mean of a sample is notated as M.
The mean of a population is notated as (\(\mu\)).

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Sampling theory

The dispersion of a sample is known as the standard deviation, or SD, or sometimes just s.
The dispersion of a population cannot be a “deviation” because we don’t actually know it. So instead, we call it the Standard Error, or SE, or most often (sigma).

title: Sampling Theory
text:
What is a hypothesis?
A hypothesis is a testable prediction of what will happen in our experiment that:

Names of the variables (independent and dependent)
Clearly contrasts the groups

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Hypothesis:
Example

Professor Brocker wants to know if Millennials enjoy the Netflix Original, Dark significantly more than Gen Z. She recruits 500 Millennials and 500 Zoomers and asks them to rate Dark on a scale of 1 to 10 (10 being fantastic).


Hypothesis: Millennials will rate their enjoyment of Dark as significantly higher than their Gen Z peers.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Hypothesis:
Example

Hypothesis: Millennials will rate their enjoyment of Dark as significantly higher than their Gen Z peers.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
What is a Hypothesis?
An Alternative Hypothesis is a testable prediction of what will happen in our experiment that:

Names of the variables (independent and dependent)
Clearly contrasts the groups.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Alternative hypothesis
An Alternative Hypothesis is a testable prediction of what will happen in our experiment that names of the variables (independent and dependent) and clearly contrasts the groups.

The Alternative Hypothesis is written as \(H_1\)

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Null Hypothesis
The Null Hypothesis states that nothing will happen. \(H_0\)
Because Null means zero, nothing, nada.
The Null Hypothesis states that nothing will happen while also:

Naming of the variables (independent and dependent)

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Alternative & Null Hypotheses:
Example
Professor Brocker’s Dark Experiment:

Alternative Hypothesis: Millennials will rate their enjoyment of Dark as significantly higher than their Gen Z peers.
Null Hypothesis: Millennials and Gen Z will not differ in their rating of enjoyment of the Eric Andre Show.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Hypothesis testing

Null Hypothesis: These is no difference in the DV between the IV groups.
Alternative Hypothesis: The experimental group is significantly different from the control group on the DV.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Rejects and Failures

In science, we do not say that we proved anything.
Nothing is ever really proven.
Our findings will be stated in terms of the Null Hypothesis.
The Null Hypothesis is that there are no differences between the groups.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Hypothesis testing practice

Jonas assigns half of the participants to engage in aerobic exercise for one hour a day 5 days a week for 6 months. The other half of the participants do not exercise for 6 months. At the end of the 6 months, Jonas measures the participants’ working memory capacity.

\(H_0\): There are no differences in working memory capacity between the experimental and control groups.

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Rejects and Failures

In science, we do not say that we proved anything.
Our findings will be stated in terms of the Null Hypothesis.
If there are significant differences between the groups, we Reject the \(H_0\).

Rejecting is good.

If there are NO differences between the groups, we Fail to Reject the \(H_0\).

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Hypothesis testing
[Include YODA picture or something similar]

title: Sampling Theory
text:
Hypothesis Testing
When reporting your findings, you must state them in terms of the Null Hypothesis. We do not mention the Alternative Hypothesis.

If the groups differ, we reject the null hypothesis: Reject \(H_0\).
If the groups do NOT differ, we fail: Fail to Reject \(H_0\)

title: Lecture
text:
Research in psychology encompasses several fields and sub-fields, however, each area adheres to the same rigorous methodological constraints.

Lecture 1: Introduction to Research


Reading | Slides

This lecture explains the concept of operationalization, or how we selectively define certain attributes or concepts. We will also discuss the different scales of measurements; nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio

Lecture 2: Operationalization | Scales of Measurement

Reading | Slides


This lecture introduces the concept of Central Tendency and some statistical tools we use to measure these such as Mean, Median, Mode, and Range.

Lecture 3: Measures of Central Tendency

Reading | Slides


In this lecture, we will discuss how ‘real’ data is often unwieldy and will vary–it is the magnitude of how much the data varies that determines our statistical decisions. We will be introduced to the statistical concepts of variance and standard deviation.

Lecture 4: Measures of Variability

Reading | Slides



Lecture 5: Normal Distributions & Z-scores

Reading | Slides


This lecture introduces the concept of standardization using z-scores and probability to determine the likelihood of some data decisions.

Lecture 6: Z-scores & Probability

Reading: Z-Scores | Reading: Probability | Slides


This lecture introduces SPSS, Excel, and R for statistical analysis and visualization.

Lecture 7: Introduction to Statistical Software



This lecture is reserved for review of Exam 1.

Lecture 8: Review for Exam 1




Lecture 9: Statistics in the Real World, Pt. 1



This lecture discusses the notion of sampling and how we draw portions from the unknown population to test hypotheses and make generalizations (when possible) about larger groups.

Lecture 10: Sampling Theory, Hypothesis Testing

Reading


The statistical concepts of Power and Effect Size will be discussed as well as seeing a crucial step in the research cycle, Meta-Analysis which analyzes the analyses of past papers.

Lecture 11: Power & Effect Size | Introduction to Meta-Analysis

Reading


This lecture discusses the how two or more variables change in accordance with the other as well as how we define the strength, and direction of a relationship between measured variables.

Lecture 12: Covariance & Correlation

Reading


This lecture discusses the statistical framework of Linear Regression which can be used to create predictive models and inferences about what might occur given a certain set of information or variables.

Lecture 13: Linear Regression

Reading


This lecture explains how more than one variable can contribute to the strength of a relationship as well as the predictive value. Other types of variables can also be used to predict states.

Lecture 14: Interactions & Categorical Variables in Linear Regression

Need Reading for this One!



Lecture 15: Statistics in the Real World, Pt 2



This lecture is reserved for a review of Exam 2

Lecture 16: Review for Exam 2



The independent samples t-test is used to test for differences between two samples that come from independent sources.

Lecture 17: Independent Samples t-Tests

Reading


The Between Subjects ANOVA is used when an Independent Variable has more than three levels and each level is composed of unique respondents.

Lecture 18: Between Subjects ANOVA

Reading


When interpreting the results of an ANOVA, you can use comparisons to test how the effects differ between each of the 3+ conditions.

Lecture 19: Comparisons



A Factorial ANOVA has 2 or more Independent Variables which leads you with possible Main Effects for each Independent Variable as well as an interaction effect between each independent Variable.

Lecture 20: Factorial ANOVA

Reading


Factorial ANOVA’s have the possibility for an interaction where the effect of a manipulation is especially powerful in the presence of a certain level of a secondary independent variable or the effect depends on a certain level of a secondary independent variable.

Lecture 21: Interactions in ANOVA

Reading


A Within-Subjects ANOVA uses the same participants in each level of an independent variable.

Lecture 22: Within Subjects ANOVA

Reading


Mixed Method ANOVA’s can have a variety of Between and Within Factors that contribute to the research design. Some respondents are exposed to one type of level within an independent variable, however, all participants are exposed to one or more conditions of a secondary independent variable.

Lecture 23: Mixed Methods ANOVA

Reading


Reliability and Validity are statistical concepts that establish criteria for independent and dependent variables as well as classifications for internal strength of a certain measure or test.

Lecture 24: Reliability & Validity

Reading



Lecture 25: Statistics in the Real World, Pt 3



APA formatting in the Results section of an academic paper will be discussed as well as the purpose and structure of the section.

Lecture 26: APA format & Results Section

Need something for this


This lecture will be reserved for review of Exam 3.

Lecture 27: Review for Exam 3





 Back to top

title: PSY348: Statistics for Psychology
text:
Catalog Course Description:
This course will introduce students to the basic descriptive and inferential statistics used in the behavioral and social sciences. Topics will include the organization of data, measures of central tendency and variability, correlation and regression, hypothesis testing, and various parametric and nonparametric tests of significance including t-tests and ANOVA. Students will focus on the interconnections between theory, statistical techniques, and research methods in order to identify the appropriate statistical tests to analyze data and reach objective conclusions regarding research questions in the social sciences. The course will provide practice in using statistical software for data summarization, presentation, and analysis.

title: PSY348: Statistics for Psychology
text:
Course Learning Outcomes:

As a result of this course, students will be able to understand statistical terms and research reports in the social sciences, use statistical techniques to analyze experimental data for hypothesis testing, and use statistical software to aid in the presentation and analysis of quantitative data.
To accomplish these objectives, students will be able to:

Describe the four measurement scales (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio).
Construct frequency distributions and represent them graphically.
Identify and calculate measures of central tendency including mean, median, and mode.
Define and calculate measures of variability including variance and standard deviation.
Calculate and apply the use of z-scores.
Describe the normal curve and use the curve to solve various problems including probability.
Appraise the difference between populations and samples.
Apply the concepts of sampling theory and sampling distributions to statistical testing.
Explain and apply the basic concepts of hypothesis testing including the null, significance testing, and errors.
Calculate and appraise correlation coefficients.
Obtain and graph regression equations and use results to make predictions.
Test for significant differences between means using t-tests.
Calculate and interpret analysis of variance and follow up comparisons.
Determine appropriate hypothesis test based on research questions and level of data.
Evaluate how appropriate measures are by measuring reliability and validity.
Perform statistical techniques by hand using formulas and with statistical software.
Interpret the results of inferential statistical techniques.

Course Format
This course has both lecture and laboratory components. During lecture on Monday and Wednesday, we will discuss statistical theory and prepare for the corresponding laboratory by examining computational formulas. We will also work through practice examples to prepare you for the recitation.
On Monday afternoons we will meet for recitation. I will guide you through the first half of the lab for that day, and students will be given the remainder of the recitation period to complete the second portion of the lab. Students will complete the labs using statistical software accessed on the computers in our classroom.

title: PSY348: Statistics for Psychology
text:

Exams (36%) – 12 points each
There will be three non-cumulative exams. Each of the exams will contain two parts: conceptional and computational. The conceptual part of the exam will include 12 multiple choice questions pertaining to theory we covered in lecture. Each multiple choice question will be worth 0.5 points for a total of 6 points. The computational part of the exam will contain 2 to 3 questions with various parts, each worth a different point value. The computational portion will require you to apply the concepts we learned in lecture and the skills we learn in recitation.

In recitation each week, students will complete a 5-point lab assignment that corresponds to the lectures given the week before. Each lab will contain two parts. The second part is to be completed by students on their own or in small groups and is worth the remaining 3 points.

Cancellation of Classes:
Weather and other campus-wide cancellations will be listed on the home page, Facebook and Twitter and you can also sign up for RAVE and SUNY Alert. Go to GETRAVE and use your Farmingdale user ID and password to enter the site. For SUNY-Alert, please visit the University Police web page at University Police. If I need to cancel class for any other reason, I will post an announcement on Brightspace and email students a copy of the announcement.
Electronic Devices Policy:
Technology use in the classroom is intended to enhance the learning environment for all students. Accordingly, use of laptops, notebook computers, and tablets is allowed in and during class so long as they are being used to take notes and they are put in silent mode so that notifications do not sound during class.
Cellphones should be put in silent mode and kept out of sight, unless there are extenuating circumstances (for example, you have a child who is being cared by someone while you are in class and you must be reachable). If you feel you need to have your cell phone out during class time for a legitimate reason, please email me.
Classroom Recording:
The recording of classroom instruction is for the sole purpose of supporting the course learning objectives and can only be accessible to FSC faculty, staff, and students. Capturing, copying, and or sharing of recordings is strictly prohibited. Students not adhering to campus policies would be in violation of the student code of conduct.
Attendance Policy:
This course requires attendance and active participation, as the material increases in difficulty over the course of the semester. Each student is allowed 2 absences without penalty, so long as missed work is made up in a timely manner. Students who are absence more than twice, should meet with me to discuss how they will keep up with the course material.
Religious Absences:
If you are unable to attend class on certain days due to religious beliefs, please consult with your instructor well in advance of the absence so that appropriate accommodation can be made. Reasonable accommodation in course work may be unavailable if a request results in a significant number of absences or substantially impacts class participation. Please note a significant number of absences is viewed as greater than 5% of class time.
Use of Email:
It is College policy that instructors and students use the Farmingdale email system or the Brightspace email system to contact one another.
Copyright Statement:
Course material accessed from Brightspace or the Farmingdale website is for the exclusive use of students who are currently enrolled in the course. Content from these systems cannot be reused or distributed without written permission of the instructor and/or the copyright holder. Duplication of materials protected by copyright, without permission of the copyright holder, is a violation of the Federal copyright law, as well as a violation of SUNY copyright policy.
Disability Services Center:
If you have a disability for which you are or may be requesting an accommodation, you are encouraged to contact both your instructor and the Disability Services Center, Sinclair Hall, Room 185, or call 934-420-2411, or 934-420–2607 as soon as possible this semester.
Campus Mental Health Services
Occasionally, students may experience problems related to excessive stress, anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues. All registered students at Farmingdale State College have access to Campus Mental Health Services, located in Sinclair Hall. There is no fee for services.
CMHS provides both short and long-term treatment for anxiety, mood disorders, acute and chronic stress disorders, and other emotional or behavioral problems that may adversely impact students’ functioning. Additionally, CMHS is available 24/7 for students who may be in crisis. You are encouraged to contact CMHS at (934) 420-2006 or cmhs@farmingdale.edu if you are having difficulties in the above areas. We are also available for consultation to help you determine whether or not services may be helpful.
Academic Integrity Policy
Because intellectual honesty is a cornerstone of all academic and scholarly work, each member of the Farmingdale State College campus community is expected to maintain academic integrity. Farmingdale State College has developed regulations concerning academic dishonesty and integrity to protect all students and to maintain an ethical academic environment. For more information, click the updated link below: Policies
It is important for you to understand the concept of plagiarism. Plagiarism is intentionally representing the words,images or ideas of another as one’s own in any academic exercise. This includes words, images or ideas in either print or electronic format.
Students who plagiarize will automatically fail the plagiarized assignment. This includes use of AI to complete writing assignments. All previously submitted assignments will then be re-assessed for plagiarism, and if plagiarism is found in any prior assignments, the grades of those assignments will also be changed to an F. I will also report any student who plagiarizes to the Dean of Students.
Diversity Equity & Inclusion:
Farmingdale State College embraces the belief that our intellectual community is enriched and enhanced by the opportunity to learn from and appreciate diversity. We strive to have a curriculum and learning environment which respects, honors and incorporates the contributions of a diverse and inclusive teaching and learning community. Your person (identity) and voice are welcomed in this classroom environment because of your value as a member of FSC’s inclusive and diverse culture. All members of this class are expected to contribute to a respectful, welcoming and inclusive environment for every other member of the class.
Student Code of Conduct
The President of the College and the Vice President for Student Affairs recognize the rights of designees including University Police, to enforce all regulations, policies, license agreements, laws and codes on campus. If any individual allegedly violates the laws, Student Code of Conduct or campus policies, a President’s designee will institute proceedings against the offender (s). For more information on the student code of conduct, see the Code of Conduct section in the current Student Handbook which can be found at this link, Student Handbook
Basic Needs Insecurity:
Your well-being is crucial to your academic success at Farmingdale State College.  If you are dealing with basic needs insecurity, please communicate with the Office of the Dean of Students at (934)420-2104. We are here to ensure that your well-being is prioritized. Resources are available to support you if you face challenges such as unstable housing, insufficient food, financial difficulties or other personal hardships.
Food Security

Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP): Many students are eligible for SNAP benefits, which provides funds for purchasing food.  For more information and assistance with applying, please contact Jamie Hawkins, Health & Wellness Center, hawkinjk@farmingdale.edu, or call 934-420-2690. You can apply online at Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP).  Health and Welfare Counsel of Long Island is available to help you complete the application.

Housing Assistance

Homeless Liaison: Jamie Hawkins, your Campus Homeless Liaison, offers confidential support to students experience housing instability.  They will connect you with campus and community resources.   
Emergency Housing: If you are experiencing housing instability or homelessness, the Residence Life Office (RLO) can assist with temporary housing solutions.  Contact them at (934)420-2010.
Affordable Housing Resources: For long-term housing support, the RLO can connect you with affordable housing options in the community.  Visit the RLO webpage for more details. 

Financial Assistance

Emergency Grants: Your campus offers emergency financial grants to assist students faculty unexpected financial hardships.  To apply, visit https://www.farmingdale.edu/scholarships/
Financial Aid: Ensure that you have applied for all available financial aid, including scholarships, grants, and loans.  Visit the Financial Aid Office or contact them (934)420-2578 for personalized assistance

Additional Support Services
Health and Wellness Center: For health-related concerns, visit the Health and Wellness Center
Academic Support: For academic assistance, contact Center for Academic Success & Tutoring

title: Syllabus
text: This course will introduce students to the basic descriptive and inferential statistics used in the behavioral and social sciences. Topics will include the organization of data, measures of central tendency and variability, correlation and regression, hypothesis testing, and various parametric and nonparametric tests of significance including t-tests and ANOVA. Students will focus on the interconnections between theory, statistical techniques, and research methods in order to identify the appropriate statistical tests to analyze data and reach objective conclusions regarding research questions in the social sciences. The course will provide practice in using statistical software for data summarization, presentation, and analysis.

title: Syllabus
text:
As a result of this course, students will be able to understand statistical terms and research reports in the social sciences, use statistical techniques to analyze experimental data for hypothesis testing, and use statistical software to aid in the presentation and analysis of quantitative data.
To accomplish these objectives, students will be able to:

Describe the four measurement scales (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio).
Construct frequency distributions and represent them graphically.
Identify and calculate measures of central tendency including mean, median, and mode.
Define and calculate measures of variability including variance and standard deviation.
Calculate and apply the use of z-scores.
Describe the normal curve and use the curve to solve various problems including probability.
Appraise the difference between populations and samples.
Apply the concepts of sampling theory and sampling distributions to statistical testing.
Explain and apply the basic concepts of hypothesis testing including the null, significance testing, and errors.
Calculate and appraise correlation coefficients.
Obtain and graph regression equations and use results to make predictions.
Test for significant differences between means using t-tests.
Calculate and interpret analysis of variance and follow up comparisons.
Determine appropriate hypothesis test based on research questions and level of data.
Evaluate how appropriate measures are by measuring reliability and validity.
Perform statistical techniques by hand using formulas and with statistical software.
Interpret the results of inferential statistical techniques.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Materials
There is no required text for this course.
Selected readings will be made available on Brightspace.
Course Format
This course has both lecture and laboratory components. During lecture on Monday and Wednesday, we will discuss statistical theory and prepare for the corresponding laboratory by examining computational formulas. We will also work through practice examples to prepare you for the recitation.
On Monday afternoons we will meet for recitation. I will guide you through the first half of the lab for that day, and students will be given the remainder of the recitation period to complete the second portion of the lab. Students will complete the labs using statistical software accessed on the computers in our classroom.

title: Syllabus
text:
Exams (36%) – 12 points each
There will be three non-cumulative exams. Each of the exams will contain two parts: conceptional and computational. The conceptual part of the exam will include 12 multiple choice questions pertaining to theory we covered in lecture. Each multiple choice question will be worth 0.5 points for a total of 6 points. The computational part of the exam will contain 2 to 3 questions with various parts, each worth a different point value. The computational portion will require you to apply the concepts we learned in lecture and the skills we learn in recitation.
Labs (54%) – 4.5 points each
In recitation each week, students will complete a 5-point lab assignment that corresponds to the lectures given the week before. Each lab will contain two parts. We will complete the first part together as a class. Working along with the class to complete the first part is worth 1.5 points. The second part is to be completed by students on their own or in small groups and is worth the remaining 3 points.
Attendance and Participation (10%)
This course requires attendance and active participation, as the material increases in difficulty over the course of the semester. Each student is allowed 2 absences without penalty, so long as missed work is made up in a timely manner. Students who are absence more than twice, should meet with me to discuss how they will keep up with the course material.

title: Lecture
text:
Research in psychology encompasses several fields and sub-fields, however, each area adheres to the same rigorous methodological constraints.

Lecture 1: Introduction to Research


Reading | Slides

This lecture explains the concept of operationalization, or how we selectively define certain attributes or concepts. We will also discuss the different scales of measurements; nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio

Lecture 2: Operationalization | Scales of Measurement

Reading | Slides


This lecture introduces the concept of Central Tendency and some statistical tools we use to measure these such as Mean, Median, Mode, and Range.

Lecture 3: Measures of Central Tendency

Reading | Slides


In this lecture, we will discuss how ‘real’ data is often unwieldy and will vary–it is the magnitude of how much the data varies that determines our statistical decisions. We will be introduced to the statistical concepts of variance and standard deviation.

Lecture 4: Measures of Variability

Reading | Slides



Lecture 5: Normal Distributions & Z-scores

Reading | Slides


This lecture introduces the concept of standardization using z-scores and probability to determine the likelihood of some data decisions.

Lecture 6: Z-scores & Probability

Reading: Z-Scores | Reading: Probability | Slides


This lecture introduces SPSS, Excel, and R for statistical analysis and visualization.

Lecture 7: Introduction to Statistical Software



This lecture is reserved for review of Exam 1.

Lecture 8: Review for Exam 1




Lecture 9: Statistics in the Real World, Pt. 1



This lecture discusses the notion of sampling and how we draw portions from the unknown population to test hypotheses and make generalizations (when possible) about larger groups.

Lecture 10: Sampling Theory, Hypothesis Testing

Reading


The statistical concepts of Power and Effect Size will be discussed as well as seeing a crucial step in the research cycle, Meta-Analysis which analyzes the analyses of past papers.

Lecture 11: Power & Effect Size | Introduction to Meta-Analysis

Reading


This lecture discusses the how two or more variables change in accordance with the other as well as how we define the strength, and direction of a relationship between measured variables.

Lecture 12: Covariance & Correlation

Reading


This lecture discusses the statistical framework of Linear Regression which can be used to create predictive models and inferences about what might occur given a certain set of information or variables.

Lecture 13: Linear Regression

Reading


This lecture explains how more than one variable can contribute to the strength of a relationship as well as the predictive value. Other types of variables can also be used to predict states.

Lecture 14: Interactions & Categorical Variables in Linear Regression

Need Reading for this One!



Lecture 15: Statistics in the Real World, Pt 2



This lecture is reserved for a review of Exam 2

Lecture 16: Review for Exam 2



The independent samples t-test is used to test for differences between two samples that come from independent sources.

Lecture 17: Independent Samples t-Tests

Reading


The Between Subjects ANOVA is used when an Independent Variable has more than three levels and each level is composed of unique respondents.

Lecture 18: Between Subjects ANOVA

Reading


When interpreting the results of an ANOVA, you can use comparisons to test how the effects differ between each of the 3+ conditions.

Lecture 19: Comparisons



A Factorial ANOVA has 2 or more Independent Variables which leads you with possible Main Effects for each Independent Variable as well as an interaction effect between each independent Variable.

Lecture 20: Factorial ANOVA

Reading


Factorial ANOVA’s have the possibility for an interaction where the effect of a manipulation is especially powerful in the presence of a certain level of a secondary independent variable or the effect depends on a certain level of a secondary independent variable.

Lecture 21: Interactions in ANOVA

Reading


A Within-Subjects ANOVA uses the same participants in each level of an independent variable.

Lecture 22: Within Subjects ANOVA

Reading


Mixed Method ANOVA’s can have a variety of Between and Within Factors that contribute to the research design. Some respondents are exposed to one type of level within an independent variable, however, all participants are exposed to one or more conditions of a secondary independent variable.

Lecture 23: Mixed Methods ANOVA

Reading


Reliability and Validity are statistical concepts that establish criteria for independent and dependent variables as well as classifications for internal strength of a certain measure or test.

Lecture 24: Reliability & Validity

Reading



Lecture 25: Statistics in the Real World, Pt 3



APA formatting in the Results section of an academic paper will be discussed as well as the purpose and structure of the section.

Lecture 26: APA format & Results Section

Need something for this


This lecture will be reserved for review of Exam 3.

Lecture 27: Review for Exam 3





 Back to top

Cancellation of Classes:
Weather and other campus-wide cancellations will be listed on the home page, Facebook and Twitter and you can also sign up for RAVE and SUNY Alert. Go to GETRAVE and use your Farmingdale user ID and password to enter the site. For SUNY-Alert, please visit the University Police web page at University Police. If I need to cancel class for any other reason, I will post an announcement on Brightspace and email students a copy of the announcement.
Electronic Devices Policy:
Technology use in the classroom is intended to enhance the learning environment for all students. Accordingly, use of laptops, notebook computers, and tablets is allowed in and during class so long as they are being used to take notes and they are put in silent mode so that notifications do not sound during class.
Cellphones should be put in silent mode and kept out of sight, unless there are extenuating circumstances (for example, you have a child who is being cared by someone while you are in class and you must be reachable). If you feel you need to have your cell phone out during class time for a legitimate reason, please email me.
Classroom Recording:
The recording of classroom instruction is for the sole purpose of supporting the course learning objectives and can only be accessible to FSC faculty, staff, and students. Capturing, copying, and or sharing of recordings is strictly prohibited. Students not adhering to campus policies would be in violation of the student code of conduct.
Attendance Policy:
This course requires attendance and active participation, as the material increases in difficulty over the course of the semester. Each student is allowed 2 absences without penalty, so long as missed work is made up in a timely manner. Students who are absence more than twice, should meet with me to discuss how they will keep up with the course material.
Religious Absences:
If you are unable to attend class on certain days due to religious beliefs, please consult with your instructor well in advance of the absence so that appropriate accommodation can be made. Reasonable accommodation in course work may be unavailable if a request results in a significant number of absences or substantially impacts class participation. Please note a significant number of absences is viewed as greater than 5% of class time.
Use of Email:
It is College policy that instructors and students use the Farmingdale email system or the Brightspace email system to contact one another.
Copyright Statement:
Course material accessed from Brightspace or the Farmingdale website is for the exclusive use of students who are currently enrolled in the course. Content from these systems cannot be reused or distributed without written permission of the instructor and/or the copyright holder. Duplication of materials protected by copyright, without permission of the copyright holder, is a violation of the Federal copyright law, as well as a violation of SUNY copyright policy.
Disability Services Center:
If you have a disability for which you are or may be requesting an accommodation, you are encouraged to contact both your instructor and the Disability Services Center, Sinclair Hall, Room 185, or call 934-420-2411, or 934-420–2607 as soon as possible this semester.
Campus Mental Health Services
Occasionally, students may experience problems related to excessive stress, anxiety, depression, and other mental health issues. All registered students at Farmingdale State College have access to Campus Mental Health Services, located in Sinclair Hall. There is no fee for services.
CMHS provides both short and long-term treatment for anxiety, mood disorders, acute and chronic stress disorders, and other emotional or behavioral problems that may adversely impact students’ functioning. Additionally, CMHS is available 24/7 for students who may be in crisis. You are encouraged to contact CMHS at (934) 420-2006 or cmhs@farmingdale.edu if you are having difficulties in the above areas. We are also available for consultation to help you determine whether or not services may be helpful.
Academic Integrity Policy
Because intellectual honesty is a cornerstone of all academic and scholarly work, each member of the Farmingdale State College campus community is expected to maintain academic integrity. Farmingdale State College has developed regulations concerning academic dishonesty and integrity to protect all students and to maintain an ethical academic environment. For more information, click the updated link below: Policies
It is important for you to understand the concept of plagiarism. Plagiarism is intentionally representing the words,images or ideas of another as one’s own in any academic exercise. This includes words, images or ideas in either print or electronic format.
Students who plagiarize will automatically fail the plagiarized assignment. This includes use of AI to complete writing assignments. All previously submitted assignments will then be re-assessed for plagiarism, and if plagiarism is found in any prior assignments, the grades of those assignments will also be changed to an F. I will also report any student who plagiarizes to the Dean of Students.
Diversity Equity & Inclusion:
Farmingdale State College embraces the belief that our intellectual community is enriched and enhanced by the opportunity to learn from and appreciate diversity. We strive to have a curriculum and learning environment which respects, honors and incorporates the contributions of a diverse and inclusive teaching and learning community. Your person (identity) and voice are welcomed in this classroom environment because of your value as a member of FSC’s inclusive and diverse culture. All members of this class are expected to contribute to a respectful, welcoming and inclusive environment for every other member of the class.
Student Code of Conduct
The President of the College and the Vice President for Student Affairs recognize the rights of designees including University Police, to enforce all regulations, policies, license agreements, laws and codes on campus. If any individual allegedly violates the laws, Student Code of Conduct or campus policies, a President’s designee will institute proceedings against the offender (s). For more information on the student code of conduct, see the Code of Conduct section in the current Student Handbook which can be found at this link, Student Handbook
Basic Needs Insecurity:
Your well-being is crucial to your academic success at Farmingdale State College.  If you are dealing with basic needs insecurity, please communicate with the Office of the Dean of Students at (934)420-2104. We are here to ensure that your well-being is prioritized. Resources are available to support you if you face challenges such as unstable housing, insufficient food, financial difficulties or other personal hardships.
Food Security

Campus food Pantry –The Food Pantry provides free groceries to students in need. More information and hours of operation are available at Food Pantry
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP): Many students are eligible for SNAP benefits, which provides funds for purchasing food.  For more information and assistance with applying, please contact Jamie Hawkins, Health & Wellness Center, hawkinjk@farmingdale.edu, or call 934-420-2690. You can apply online at Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP).  Health and Welfare Counsel of Long Island is available to help you complete the application.

Housing Assistance

Homeless Liaison: Jamie Hawkins, your Campus Homeless Liaison, offers confidential support to students experience housing instability.  They will connect you with campus and community resources.   
Emergency Housing: If you are experiencing housing instability or homelessness, the Residence Life Office (RLO) can assist with temporary housing solutions.  Contact them at (934)420-2010.
Affordable Housing Resources: For long-term housing support, the RLO can connect you with affordable housing options in the community.  Visit the RLO webpage for more details. 

Financial Assistance

Emergency Grants: Your campus offers emergency financial grants to assist students faculty unexpected financial hardships.  To apply, visit https://www.farmingdale.edu/scholarships/
Financial Aid: Ensure that you have applied for all available financial aid, including scholarships, grants, and loans.  Visit the Financial Aid Office or contact them (934)420-2578 for personalized assistance

Additional Support Services
Health and Wellness Center: For health-related concerns, visit the Health and Wellness Center
Academic Support: For academic assistance, contact Center for Academic Success & Tutoring

title: Welcome!

Info
Name: Professor Brocker
Background: 7+ years of teaching stats, turning confusion into clarity.
Education: Master’s in Experimental Psychology (specializing in Morality and Emotion).

title: Welcome!
text:
Why are we here?
To turn confusion into confidence and numbers into knowledge!

title: Welcome!
text:
What is Statistics? 🤔

The art of turning data into… more confusing data (just kidding!).
It’s the science of making sense of the world through numbers.

title: Welcome!
text:
But Seriously, What is Statistics?
Statistics is the science of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data to make informed decisions.
Translation:
“We help people who hate math feel smart with numbers!”

title: Welcome!

Why Should You Care? 🤓

Because data is everywhere, even in your favorite Netflix recommendations!
Knowing stats can help you win arguments on the internet with facts.
It’s like having a superpower—just without the cape.

title: Measures of Central Tendency
text:
Measures of Central tendency

Mean

the average; obtained by summing all values and dividing by the number of values.
\(\sum^{n}_{i=1} = x_1 + x_2...\)

Median

The middle number; obtained by ordering all values from lowest to highest and taking the middle (if n is odd or the average of the 2 middle if n is even)

Mode

the most frequent answer; obtained by counting how many times each answer is given and taking the value that occurs most often

We overwhelmingly use the mean, because in the social and behavioral sciences, we nearly always assume the distribution is normal.

In a skewed distribution, the mean gets pulled out toward the tail, and the mode gets pulled to the cluster.
The median is the best measure of central tendency for skewed distributions because it tells us how most people answered.

Calculating The mean

Sum all x values
Divide by the number of x values (n).

x = 4,2,5,6
\(\frac{\Sigma(x)}{n}\)
\(\Sigma(x) = 4 + 2 + 5 + 6 = 17\)
\(\frac{17}{4} = 4.25\)

Put all x values in order from smallest or largest or largest to smallest.

x = 4,2,5,6,3

Put all x values in order from smallest or largest or largest to smallest. \(x = [3,2,1,5,3,7,8,3,2,4,1]\)
Find the number or numbers that repeat the most. \(x = [1,1,2,2,3,3,3,4,5,7,8]\)
There can be more than 1 mode.

title: Z-scores & Probability
text:
Review

68.3% of the datapoints (the X’s) will fall within 1 SD of the mean.
95.4% of the datapoints (the X’s) will fall within 2 SD of the mean.
99.7% of the datapoints (the X’s) will fall within 3 SD of the mean.

Z-scores are expressed in Standard Deviation units.

title: Z-scores & Probability
text:
Z-scores
Z-scores re-express the original data points (the X’s) in a way that intuitively lets us know:

How close the X is to the mean
Where it falls in the dispersion of the distribution
how much this participant is like the other person in the sample
Where it falls in the dispersion of the distribution
how different this participant is from the majority of people in the sample

title: Z-scores & Probability
text:
Z-scores
Z-scores are expressed in Standard Deviation units.

z = 1
z = -2
z = 0.5

title: Z-scores & Probability
text:
Calculating A Z-score

Mean-center the X values —> X — X —> Makes the Mean = 0.
Dividing by the standard deviation —> Makes the SD = 1.

How do we calculate the probability of an outcome, using the normal distribution?

Use a z-score:
Mean center the X values.
Divide them by the SD.

title: Z-scores & Probability
section: How do we calculate the probability of an outcome, using the normal distribution?
text:
How do we calculate the probability of an outcome, using the normal distribution?

The average grade on the exam was an 86 with a standard deviation of 4.
What is the probability of scoring a 94 or higher on the exam?

\(z = \frac{x-\bar{x}}{s}\)
\(z = \frac{94-86}{4} = \frac{8}{4}=2\)
\(z = 2\)

Z = 2 corresponds with 2.1% and 0.1% of the curve 2.2% chance.

title: Z-scores & Probability
text:
Example 2
The mean exam score was 86 with a standard deviation of 4.
What is the probability of scoring between an 82 and a 90?
\(z = \frac{82-86}{4} = \frac{-4}{4} = -1\)
\(z = \frac{90-86}{4} = \frac{4}{4} = 1\)

68.3% chance of scoring between 82 and 90.

title: Z-scores & Probability
text:
Example 3

Esmeralda’s stats professor tells her class that the average score on the exam was a 72 with a standard deviation of 6, and the distribution of scores was normal.

Esmeralda wants to calculate the probability that she scored below 60
\(\frac{60-72}{6} = \frac{-12}{6} = -2\)

2.2% chance that she failed.
What’s the chance she passed?

title: Z-scores & Probability
text:
Z-scores and Probability
In real life, we are often working with numbers with long decimal points rather than nice whole numbers.

Because the standard normal curve is STANDARD and NORMAL, we can calculate the exact probability of a z-score with a decimal point.
Calculate the z-score.
Locate the whole number and first decimal point along the left side of the table.
Locate the second decimal point along the top of the table.

text:

If you need that z-score or higher, you have to subtract the decimal from 1.

title: Z-scores & Probability

Some examples

In a recent study on world happiness, participants were asked to evaluate their current lives on a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 represents the worst possible life and 10 represents the best possible life. The responses were normally distributed, with a mean of 5.4 and a standard deviation of 2.2. Find the probability that a randomly selected study participant’s response was:


Less than 4
More than 8
